content:
I've noticed just by observing their effect that left takes the first single statement in a disjunctive goal, and that right takes the tail, which could be a disjunction of one or more statements.

To me this is like the head and tail used in many languages operating on a list or stack.

Is this correct?

I'm asking because I've not seen it explained that way, and only observed this behaviour.

Example: for a goal P ∨ Q ∨ R ∨ S we have:

  • left is P
  • right is Q ∨ R ∨ S
  • right then left is Q
That's because p ∨ q ∨ r is parsed as p ∨ (q ∨ r).
But unlike appending lists, logical disjunction is commutative, so this is really an "accident" of the parsing conventions
Unless you want to give special meaning to the same fact plain addition too
